translation.s:
the clouds gathered over the sea.
See

ul.s: Captain, don't you hear the thunder?
I even hear the birds on the wind.
Captain, so you don't get tossed off the ship
as I managed to fall into the hold.
Captain, stay afloat near the ship,
as we come out of the eye of the storm for you.
the rock if you can reach it
as I latch to the crow's nest keeping you at point.
the salty waters, Captain, close your mouth.
The memory of that night makes me taste tears.
as I'm sick from our loss.
and we smell the new vacant day.

translation.s: Alone, the dawn directs us forward;

vowel.history:
On the very first notes page, for water, I have, "time, music, storm, thunder, lightning, navy (could only defend), (maybe) rainbow, drowning, fish, birds, waves--moon, compass/magnetism, clouds--parents to ocean, rain [homage (undesired or not)]"
Waters was inspired partly by the first two verses of Genesis: "In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth. And the earth was without form, and void; and darkness was upon the face of the deep. And the Spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters." Thus, God didn't create water, it was there 'in the beginning.' As a generalization I've noticed in the Bible and most other places, water representing the 'other' of nature or that which exerts the force of an unsympathetic nature.
